title: The Acorns of Obedience
sub_title: Surrendering to the Rhythm of God's Plan
devotional:
Old Mr. Abernathy, a man known for his meticulous lawn and unwavering adherence to the neighborhood bylaws, stood as a testament to order. He spent his days ensuring that every blade of grass was precisely three inches tall, every flowerbed perfectly symmetrical, and every trash can placed just so. One blustery autumn day, a mighty oak in his yard began dropping acorns with abandon. They landed everywhere: on his pristine lawn, in his meticulously arranged flowerbeds, and even bounced off his freshly washed windows. Mr. Abernathy, normally unflappable, was beside himself. He raked, he swept, he even tried to reason with the tree, but to no avail. The acorns kept falling, a defiant act against his carefully constructed world of order.

Finally, exhausted and defeated, he sat on his porch, watching the acorns pile up. His neighbor, a woman named Mrs. Peterson, known for her wild garden and even wilder spirit, strolled over. She didn't offer platitudes or suggestions for acorn removal. Instead, she simply pointed to a squirrel busily burying an acorn. "You know, Mr. Abernathy," she said, her eyes twinkling, "those acorns are seeds of promise. They may disrupt your order now, but they hold the potential for new life."

Mr. Abernathy looked at the acorns with new eyes. He realized that his obsession with control had blinded him to the beauty of nature's cycle, to the inherent messiness of growth, and to the simple truth that obedience to nature's rhythm often meant surrendering his rigid expectations. Just as the oak tree was obeying its nature by producing acorns, so too were we called to obey God's plan, even when it disrupted our own carefully laid plans.

Obedience to God is not about adhering to a set of rules; it is about aligning ourselves with His will, trusting that even the disruptions and apparent chaos are part of a larger, more beautiful design. It's about recognizing that sometimes, the most fruitful path is the one that leads us through the unraked leaves and unsymmetrical flowerbeds of life, trusting that God's plan, like the promise hidden within the acorn, will eventually bring forth abundant life.
image_description: A sprawling oak tree in autumn, dropping acorns onto a meticulously manicured lawn, with fallen leaves scattered about.
insights: The story of Mr. Abernathy illustrates the tension between our desire for control and the call to obedience. 1 Samuel 15:22 states, 'Does the Lord delight in burnt offerings and sacrifices as much as in obeying the Lord’s voice? Surely obedience is better than sacrifice, and submission is better than the fat of rams.' This verse highlights that true obedience is not about outward acts of religious devotion, but about a willing submission to God's will, even when it challenges our own preferences and expectations.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I confess that I often struggle with obedience. I cling to my own plans and desires, resisting Your guidance when it disrupts my sense of control. Help me to surrender my will to Yours, trusting that Your plan is always better, even when I can't see the full picture. Grant me the wisdom to recognize Your voice amidst the noise of my own ambitions, and the courage to follow You, even into the unraked leaves and unsymmetrical flowerbeds of life. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: In what areas of your life are you clinging to control, resisting God's call to obedience? What small step can you take today to surrender your will to His? How can you reframe your perspective to see disruptions and challenges as opportunities for growth and alignment with God's plan?
